VOL. XXXII, No. 35

MUSICAL CLUB
CONCERT TONIGHT
Annual Home Concert to Climax
Successful Season
IULA TO PLAY AT DANCE
Twelve Attractive Numbers Make
Up Elaborate Program
Tonight at eight-thirty sharp
the Musical Club will make its
supreme effort- to climax a successful season with a memorable
home concert. The concert, which
will be held as usual at the Maryland Casualty Auditorium, has become an event of the collegiate
year which is looked forward to
by most Hopkins undergraduates
and this year promises to be no
exception. Ticket sales to date
at the Barn and at Albaugh's indicate that the attendance will
surpass all previous records.
As usual a dance will follow the
concert in the Maryland Casualty
ballroom but this year Bob Iula's
Orchestra will play. In former
Years the Blue Jay's have furnished the music at this affair and
the hiring of an outside orchestra
Is a distinctly new idea.

RACQUET WIELDERS
WILL MEET MONDAY
Kenneth C. Proctor, captain of the tennis team, announced that there will be
an organization meeting at
12:30 Monday in room 109,
M. E. Building. All candidates for the team are expected to report at this time.
There are several places
open on the team, and everyone with any ability will find
it profitable to attend this
meeting. Proctor and Polan
are the only veterans who
have returned this year, and
the future of the team will
depend largely on the candidates who attend Monday's
meeting.

HILLTOPPERS DOWN
BLUE JAY CAGERS
Georgetown Defeats Hopkins
In Return Game At
Evergreen
Georgetown proved that its first
victory over Hopkins was no fluke
by duplicating the performance
Wednesday night at Evergreen. The
final score was 41-34.

HERSHEY TO HEAD
DANCE COMMITTEE
Due to pressure of other
work, W. B. Banks has been
forced to resign the chairmanship of the Junior Dance
Committee. Garland Hershey was elected in his stead.
At a meeting of the cornmittee held Tuesday at the
Barn, various matters concerning the dance were discussed. In keeping with tradition, it was decided to have
a costume affair. The date
is still indefinite. If permission is obtained, the dance
will be held in the Civil Engineering Building.
Other members of the
committee are Helfrisch,
Driver and Hecht.

MASSEY STRESSES
BALANCED LIFE
Urges
Minister
Canadian
Broad Cultural Training

SPEAKS

AT

EXERCISES

Dr. Goodnow Indicates Need of
Study of -Humanities

Need of balanced existence, especially during the student's university career, was emphasized by the
Honorable Charles Vincent Massey
at the fifty-second commemoration
exercises of this University, held at
the Peabody Conservatory Wednesday. Mr. Massey, Canadian Minister to the United States, delivered
the principal address of the day.
Mr. Massey drew two points to
the attention of his audience. The
first was the fact that he spoke from
the standpoint of the layman, urging a balanced career for students;
the second was the announcement of
the congratulations and feeling of
good will expressed by Canadian
universities; many of them have
long admired and even copied the
methods of Johns Hopkins.
Discuss Oiler

Osler's connection with the University, and with England, and especially his balanced life, were emphasized by Mr. Massey. The
speaker also stated that "we might
well place the modern university
along with religion and the State as
the third member of a triad to
which our devotion is pure."
The Canadian Minister deplored
the tendency in modern education to
lose the sense of harmony and proportion. The narrow specialization
of scientific students he characterized as harmful.
"An ill-balanced life," Mr. Massey declared, "cannot produce even
the useful expert."
Mr. Randall Speaks

Blanchard Randall, speaking for
the Board of Trustees in the absence of Mr. Willard, mad an announcement following Mr. Massey's address in which he said that
a committee had been appointed to
select a successor to President
Goodnow. "It will be a long, long
time before Dr. Goodnow leaves
the Johns Hopkins University,"
said Mr. Randall. "The committee
has been looking for a successor. It
hopes to have an announcement in
due course and that the announcement will be made by Dr. Goodnow
himself."
Dr. Goodnow acknowledged Mr.
Randall's remarks, and spoke briefly
on the need of encouraging the
study of the Humanities. The necessity of cultivating a better understanding of the East was stressed in
his address.
Tannhauser March, Ave Mariu,
and Victory, the late Edwin L.
Turnbull's military march, were rendered at the exercises by the Johns
Hopkins Orchestra, Bart Wirtz,
conductor. The faculty and guests
filed on to the stage during the playing of the Tannhauser March. Rev.
Henri Wiesel delivered the invocation.

The meet with William and Mary
is the first of three important competitions that the Jay runners hope
to win. The William and Mary
trackmen have been practicing all
Winter on an indoor track, and it
is expected that they will prove formidable opponents.
The University of Richmond is
also likely to prove a stumbling
block.

AN APPRECIATION
On behalf of the student body of this University, we extend
our most sincere thanks to Loyola College for her generosity in
offering to the Hopkins basketball team the use of the Loyola
gymnasium. Loyola's action is particularly gracious, may we be
permitted to say, in view of the unfortunate pettinesses that have
arisen in past relations between her and Johns Hopkins. For this
reason, therefore, her offer will be even more appreciated, and is,
moreover, an omen of an era of good will between the two colleges.

REVERIE
Within the next two months the class of 1928 will have resigned
its offices in the activities of the college, will have finished a complete course in reminiscences, and have begun to worry about what
will become of them in June. Oh, yes, some few poor scapegoats
will continue to slave on through May: the editors of the Hullabaloo, the recipients of Phi Beta Kappa who feel that they must
continue to uphold their hard-earned standards, and, with unfeigned anxiety, those seniors who must get 7.0's in all their
subjects in order to graduate.
Some one hundred and twenty-five men will receive degrees in
June, and then sever their official connections with Hopkins. They
will become engineers, or medical students, or Babbitts, or law students, or loafers in their fathers' offices, or maybe even teachers
or coaches or candidates for Ph. D.'s. The graduates of the School
of Business Economics can always ,secure positions With prosperous insurance companies or bond houses, or the street railways company; the E. E.'s and M. E.'s and the C. E.'s can always,
in a pinch, work for the Army or the city; the plain, ordinary
liberally educated bachelors of arts may drift into almost anything
from phrenology down to selling shoes. All of them, anyhow,
will suddenly find out that it isn't nearly as pleasant to be at work
at 8.30 every morning and sit around waiting for something to
win up, because one has to eat, than to go to a pleasant 9.30, take
notes or not take notes, as the spirit moves one, do a bit of cursory
collateral reading, and take from an hour to the whole afternoon
for lunch! •
By this time, probably, we have been maligned for dragging any
patient reader this far without having said one single thing that
he, poor soul, didn't know before. And besides, it's too early in
the year for this sort of thing. But we insist that we have a purpose in mind (not that purposes are always necessary). Remember, ye seniors, that very soon ye will become part of the economic
system of this world: he who would exist, and would surround
himself with the amenities and luxuries of existence, must work.
Now ye play: gather ye thy rosebuds.

Henry L. Mencken, ma- rather
‘radical critic, in a recent statement
regarding Greek letter societies airs
some rather interesting 'views on
the subject. "Regarding fraternities," he. says, "I know nothing.
It is commonly alleged .that they
foster snobbery., But I see-no objection to snobbery per se all rational men are snobs in some way
or another. That fraternities exalt
fifth raters and overlook men of
merit may be true, but. this accusation might be leveled against any
other human institution."

The ancient question of the freedom of the press is again up for
discussion—this time at Lake Forest College, where the Student
Council is up in arms over the fact
that the editor of the campus paper
refuses to limit himself strictly to
campus happenings. A conference
of the two was held, which ended
in a deadlock, and The Stentor is
still grazing in foreign pastures
while the Council is threatening
drastic action.
*

The results of a survey of 44 colleges and universities show that in
23 of these institutions those students engaged in athletic activities
had a lower scholastic rating than
those not engaged in such competition. In fourteen of the colleges
athletes had a higher average, while
In five both groups were given equal
ratings.

Monday marked the first practice of the Hopkins quint in the
Loyola gymnasium and Wednesday the first game played on the
new home court.

President Goodnow
Addresses Alumni
"While in the University my purpose has been to raise the standard
of the Johns Hopkins to the scholastic ideals formulated when the
University first came into existence," said Dr. Frank J. Goodnow,
addressing the annual banquet of
the alumni association . held last
Wednesday.
Dr. Goodnow emphasized the new
ruling calling for an average of 8
in the sophomore year and called
attention to the fact that a recent
survey has indicated that the salaries
of students graduated.from colleges
vary in direct proportion to their
marks in college.
Dr. Ames also delivered a short
address to the well-crowded alumni
meeting-.

Score 23-19
Fighting every inch of the way,
a plucky Hopkins team went down
to defeat before 'an equally hardstruggling quint from Maryland, by
the score of 23-19, at College Park
last Tuesday.
Bodily contact, long, wild passes,
brilliant individual play, frequent
fouls, players -struggling on the
floor, .all characterized- the.:game.
From the bystanders' point of view
it was ideal; from the standpoint
of good basketball it left something
to be desired; as to individual brilliancy, it was excellent.

MUSICAL CLUB
CONCERT TONIGHT
Annual Home Concert to Climax
Successful Season
IULA TO PLAY AT DANCE
Twelve Attractive Numbers Make
Up Elaborate Program
Tonight at eight-thirty sharp
the Musical Club will make its
supreme effort- to climax a successful season with a memorable
home concert. The concert, which
will be held as usual at the Maryland Casualty Auditorium, has become an event of the collegiate
year which is looked forward to
by most Hopkins undergraduates
and this year promises to be no
exception. Ticket sales to date
at the Barn and at Albaugh's indicate that the attendance will
surpass all previous records.
As usual a dance will follow the
concert in the Maryland Casualty
ballroom but this year Bob Iula's
Orchestra will play. In former
Years the Blue Jay's have furnished the music at this affair and
the hiring of an outside orchestra
Is a distinctly new idea.

RACQUET WIELDERS
WILL MEET MONDAY
Kenneth C. Proctor, captain of the tennis team, announced that there will be
an organization meeting at
12:30 Monday in room 109,
M. E. Building. All candidates for the team are expected to report at this time.
There are several places
open on the team, and everyone with any ability will find
it profitable to attend this
meeting. Proctor and Polan
are the only veterans who
have returned this year, and
the future of the team will
depend largely on the candidates who attend Monday's
meeting.

HILLTOPPERS DOWN
BLUE JAY CAGERS
Georgetown Defeats Hopkins
In Return Game At
Evergreen
Georgetown proved that its first
victory over Hopkins was no fluke
by duplicating the performance
Wednesday night at Evergreen. The
final score was 41-34.

is still indefinite. If permission is obtained, the dance
will be held in the Civil Engineering Building.

committee are Helfrisch,
Driver and Hecht.

MASSEY STRESSES
BALANCED LIFE
Urges
Minister
Canadian
Broad Cultural Training

SPEAKS

AT

EXERCISES

Dr. Goodnow Indicates Need of
Study of -Humanities

Need of balanced existence, especially during the student's university career, was emphasized by the
Honorable Charles Vincent Massey
at the fifty-second commemoration
exercises of this University, held at
the Peabody Conservatory Wednesday. Mr. Massey, Canadian Minister to the United States, delivered
the principal address of the day.
Mr. Massey drew two points to
the attention of his audience. The
first was the fact that he spoke from
the standpoint of the layman, urging a balanced career for students;
the second was the announcement of
the congratulations and feeling of
good will expressed by Canadian
universities; many of them have
long admired and even copied the
methods of Johns Hopkins.
Discuss Oiler

Osler's connection with the University, and with England, and especially his balanced life, were emphasized by Mr. Massey. The
speaker also stated that "we might
well place the modern university
along with religion and the State as
the third member of a triad to
which our devotion is pure."
The Canadian Minister deplored
the tendency in modern education to
lose the sense of harmony and proportion. The narrow specialization
of scientific students he characterized as harmful.
"An ill-balanced life," Mr. Massey declared, "cannot produce even
the useful expert."
Mr. Randall Speaks

Blanchard Randall, speaking for
the Board of Trustees in the absence of Mr. Willard, mad an announcement following Mr. Massey's address in which he said that
a committee had been appointed to
select a successor to President
Goodnow. "It will be a long, long
time before Dr. Goodnow leaves
the Johns Hopkins University,"
said Mr. Randall. "The committee
has been looking for a successor. It
hopes to have an announcement in
due course and that the announcement will be made by Dr. Goodnow
himself."
Dr. Goodnow acknowledged Mr.
Randall's remarks, and spoke briefly
on the need of encouraging the
study of the Humanities. The necessity of cultivating a better understanding of the East was stressed in
his address.
Tannhauser March, Ave Mariu,
and Victory, the late Edwin L.
Turnbull's military march, were rendered at the exercises by the Johns
Hopkins Orchestra, Bart Wirtz,
conductor. The faculty and guests
filed on to the stage during the playing of the Tannhauser March. Rev.
Henri Wiesel delivered the invocation.

is expected that they will prove formidable opponents.
The University of Richmond is
also likely to prove a stumbling
block.

AN APPRECIATION
On behalf of the student body of this University, we extend
our most sincere thanks to Loyola College for her generosity in
offering to the Hopkins basketball team the use of the Loyola
gymnasium. Loyola's action is particularly gracious, may we be
permitted to say, in view of the unfortunate pettinesses that have
arisen in past relations between her and Johns Hopkins. For this
reason, therefore, her offer will be even more appreciated, and is,
moreover, an omen of an era of good will between the two colleges.

REVERIE
Within the next two months the class of 1928 will have resigned
its offices in the activities of the college, will have finished a complete course in reminiscences, and have begun to worry about what
will become of them in June. Oh, yes, some few poor scapegoats
will continue to slave on through May: the editors of the Hullabaloo, the recipients of Phi Beta Kappa who feel that they must
continue to uphold their hard-earned standards, and, with unfeigned anxiety, those seniors who must get 7.0's in all their
subjects in order to graduate.
Some one hundred and twenty-five men will receive degrees in
June, and then sever their official connections with Hopkins. They
will become engineers, or medical students, or Babbitts, or law students, or loafers in their fathers' offices, or maybe even teachers
or coaches or candidates for Ph. D.'s. The graduates of the School
of Business Economics can always ,secure positions With prosperous insurance companies or bond houses, or the street railways company; the E. E.'s and M. E.'s and the C. E.'s can always,
in a pinch, work for the Army or the city; the plain, ordinary
liberally educated bachelors of arts may drift into almost anything
from phrenology down to selling shoes. All of them, anyhow,
will suddenly find out that it isn't nearly as pleasant to be at work
at 8.30 every morning and sit around waiting for something to
win up, because one has to eat, than to go to a pleasant 9.30, take
notes or not take notes, as the spirit moves one, do a bit of cursory
collateral reading, and take from an hour to the whole afternoon
for lunch! •
By this time, probably, we have been maligned for dragging any
patient reader this far without having said one single thing that
he, poor soul, didn't know before. And besides, it's too early in
the year for this sort of thing. But we insist that we have a purpose in mind (not that purposes are always necessary). Remember, ye seniors, that very soon ye will become part of the economic
system of this world: he who would exist, and would surround
himself with the amenities and luxuries of existence, must work.
Now ye play: gather ye thy rosebuds.

Henry L. Mencken, ma- rather
‘radical critic, in a recent statement
regarding Greek letter societies airs
some rather interesting 'views on
the subject. "Regarding fraternities," he. says, "I know nothing.

The ancient question of the freedom of the press is again up for
discussion—this time at Lake Forest College, where the Student
Council is up in arms over the fact
that the editor of the campus paper
refuses to limit himself strictly to
campus happenings. A conference
of the two was held, which ended
in a deadlock, and The Stentor is
still grazing in foreign pastures
while the Council is threatening
drastic action.

23 of these institutions those students engaged in athletic activities
had a lower scholastic rating than
those not engaged in such competition. In fourteen of the colleges
athletes had a higher average, while
In five both groups were given equal
ratings.

President Goodnow
Addresses Alumni
"While in the University my purpose has been to raise the standard
of the Johns Hopkins to the scholastic ideals formulated when the
University first came into existence," said Dr. Frank J. Goodnow,
addressing the annual banquet of
the alumni association . held last
Wednesday.
Dr. Goodnow emphasized the new
ruling calling for an average of 8
in the sophomore year and called
attention to the fact that a recent
survey has indicated that the salaries
of students graduated.from colleges
vary in direct proportion to their
marks in college.
Dr. Ames also delivered a short
address to the well-crowded alumni
meeting-.

Fighting every inch of the way,
a plucky Hopkins team went down
to defeat before 'an equally hardstruggling quint from Maryland, by
the score of 23-19, at College Park
last Tuesday.
Bodily contact, long, wild passes,
brilliant individual play, frequent
fouls, players -struggling on the
